 Seems to be a pretty convenient verse to throw around. Does anyone who actually quotes the Bible bother to look up the Hebrew meanings? I don't think so. 
 
 You have to remember that the OT is wrote in Hebrew, Chaldean, and some Arabic. For the most part, words we use today, will have the same meaning. But in some instances they DON'T. 
 
 Take the word "kill" for an example. If you own a Bible dictionary or concordance then it should inform you that the word kill in the Ten Commandments means to commit manslaughter. There is alot more to the actual commentary on this word and it is quite interesting. 
 
 
 But to say that killing was breaking a specific commandment and to use that as a reasoning against capital punishment is wrong. How do you explain all the wars that rage after the commandments were penned? How do you explain the cities of refuge set up for those folks quilty of accidentally killing another person.  The polls are 'terrible' because they disagree with you.
 
 
ABC News/Washington Post Poll. Dec. 15-18, 2005. N=1,003 adults nationwide. MoE ± 3. Fieldwork by TNS. RV = registered voters
 
 "Do you think abortion should be legal in all cases, legal in most cases, illegal in most cases, or illegal in all cases?"

 
 From 12/15-18/05:
 17% said legal in all cases, 40% said legal in most cases, 27% illegal in most cases, 13% illegal in all cases and 3% were unsure.
 
 
 NBC News/Wall Street Journal Poll conducted by the polling organizations of Peter Hart (D) and Bill McInturff (R). Dec. 9-12, 2005. N=approx. 500 adults nationwide. MoE ± 4.4.
 
 "The Supreme Court's 1973 Roe versus Wade decision established a woman's constitutional right to an abortion, at least in the first three months of pregnancy. Would you like to see the Supreme Court completely overturn its Roe versus Wade decision, or not?"

 
 From 12/9-12/05:
 30% said to overturn, 66% said not to overturn and 4% were unsure.
 
 Another about Roe v Wade:
 
 Pew Research Center/Pew Forum on Religion & Public Life survey conducted by Princeton Survey Research Associates International. Nov. 3-6, 2005. Adults nationwide.
 
 "In 1973 the Roe versus Wade decision established a woman's constitutional right to an abortion, at least in the first three months of pregnancy. Would you like to see the Supreme Court completely overturn its Roe versus Wade decision, or not?" Form 1 (N=589, MoE ± 4.5)

 
 From 11/3-6/05:
 26% said "yes", 65% said "no" and 9% were unsure. 
 
 
 
 CBS News/New York Times Poll. Dec. 2-6, 2005. N=1,155 adults nationwide. MoE ± 3.
 
 "Which of these comes closest to your view? Abortion should be generally available to those who want it. OR, Abortion should be available, but under stricter limits than it is now. OR, Abortion should not be permitted."

 
 From 12/2-6/05:
 38% said generally available, 39% said stricter limits, 20% said not permitted and 3% were unsure.
 
 This is a bit more direct to the question of a national ban:
 
 [Would you favor or oppose] "[a] constitutional amendment to ban abortion in all circumstances, except when necessary to save the life of the mother"
 
 
 From 11/11-13/05:
 37% said they would favor such an amendment, 61% said they would oppose such an amendment and 2% said they were unsure. 
 
 Generally speaking, people would like to see more restriction. However, the overwhelming majority also support unrestricted abortion in the first part of the pregnancy (which Roe allows), so it is valid to say that the "more restriction" is only in the later part of the pregnancy.

 My point is in the thread title. I never ever think badly of anyone that has different ideas and viewpoints from my own. I always figure that at least half of mine are retarded. I also don't feel that I need to change the mind of one single pro-lifer. I don't have to. I'm arguing on the side of the law. Which means that many people, with more book-learnin' than me, have decided what is good and right and just. It just so happens that I side with them on this issue.

 In many times, yes. However, the poll you cite is an anomoly. There are many polls that ask a very similar question which shows opposite results. One poll by itself shows little, but many polls that show results from many segments of the population can give a cross-section of what people think.
 
 

 Your data is very old and my data contradicts itself. In fact yours does too....there is no scienctific significance to 2months 30days and 3months 1 day...its just a random point so what is the logic behind that?

 
 There doesn't necessarily have to be logic behind what people believe. That is all polls show, what people believe. They ask many different questions for this very reason, so they can get a feeling of how people feel about specific situations instead of relying on a broader question. The issue is also complex, and the questions, in many instances, intermix what people personally believe and what they believe the law should reflect.
 
 Laws cannot follow the myriad of different beliefs of people because, yes, they would contradict each other.
 
 

 Even so, your old poll says people don't want abortion if they can't afford it...but then they say its ok in the 1st 3 months. So which is it?

 
 I think they interpret the question as "would you agree with abortion in this specific situation". I also think people generally don't agree with that reason today, but they believe a woman should have the unrestricted choice in the first 3 months.
 
 

 I'd say many people haven't thought about the issue and are just going with what sounds good. "abortion because the women is mentally not ok...oh that sounds aweful..she can have an abortion"...I don't think people realize that you kill a human in the process. If you asked the question "do you think the women should have the right to kill her unborn child because she is feeling depressed?" you might get a different answer.

 
 First off, "mentally ill" encompasses more than simply "depressed". Secondly, using emotionally charged words generally negate the usefulness of polls since the question is leading. If they ask "Do you think it should be legal for a woman to murder her unborn child just because she wants to during the first trimester of pregnancy" they would not get a useful cross-section. Using emotionally charged words to lead the subject negates an objective response.
